sub_topic: Finding the phase shift of trigonometric functions
message_1: A sinusoidal function of the form y = 3sin(2x - π/4) is being graphed. What is the phase shift of the function?
message_2:
The phase shift of a sinusoidal function is the horizontal shift of the graph from its standard position. In the given function y = 3sin(2x - π/4), the phase shift can be found by looking at the term inside the sine function.

The general form of a sinusoidal function is y = A sin(B(x - C)) + D, where A is the amplitude, B is the frequency, C is the phase shift, and D is the vertical shift.

In our case, we have y = 3sin(2(x - π/8)). Comparing this to the general form, we can see that the phase shift C is π/8.

So, the phase shift of the function is π/8.
